docs.title: 📝 Complete Markdown Syntax Cheatsheet
docs.text: This page contains every commonly used Markdown syntax Useful for writing notes, docs, and interview prep.

docs.title: 2️⃣ Paragraphs
docs.text:
Just write text normally.

This is a paragraph.
This is another line.

docs.title: Language highlighting
docs.text:
```java
System.out.println("Hello");

---

# 9️⃣ Blockquotes

```md
> This is a quote

This is a quote

docs.title: 1️⃣1️⃣ Tables
docs.text:
| Name | Age |
|------|------|
| Ram | 25 |
| Sam | 26 |
Name Age Ram 25 Sam 26

docs.title: 1️⃣4️⃣ Footnotes
docs.text:
Here is a footnote[^1]

[^1]: This is note

docs.title: 1️⃣6️⃣ Admonitions (Material feature)
docs.text:
!!! note
    This is note

!!! warning
    Be careful

!!! tip
    Useful trick

docs.title: 1️⃣9️⃣ Mermaid Diagrams
docs.text:
```mermaid
graph LR
A --> B

---

# 2️⃣0️⃣ Keyboard Keys

```md
++ctrl+c++

++ctrl+c++

docs.title: 2️⃣8️⃣ Highlighted Code Copy (Material)
docs.text:
Automatically appears for code blocks.

No config needed.

docs.title: 🚀 Pro Tips
docs.text: ✅ Use tables for comparisons ✅ Use checklists for revision ✅ Use admonitions for notes ✅ Use Mermaid for diagrams ✅ Keep files small

docs.title: 🎯 Quick Example
docs.text:
## HashMap vs ConcurrentHashMap

| Feature | HashMap | ConcurrentHashMap |
|----------|-----------|-------------------|
Thread Safe | ❌ | ✅ |

docs.title: ✅ Done
docs.text: You now know complete Markdown syntax for writing docs efficiently.

docs.title: What are Control Flow Statements?
docs.text:
Control flow statements determine the order in which program instructions are executed.

By default, Java executes statements sequentially (top to bottom). Control flow statements allow a program to:

  • make decisions
  • repeat actions
  • transfer execution control

Control flow statements are classified into three categories:

  1. Decision-Making Statements
  2. Looping Statements
  3. Branching (Jump) Statements

docs.title: Decision-Making Statements
docs.text:
Decision-making statements allow the program to choose which block of code should execute based on a condition.

Java provides two decision-making statements:

  • if
  • switch

docs.title: if Statement
docs.text: The if statement executes a block of code only when the given condition evaluates to true.

docs.title: Simple if Statement
docs.text: Executes code only if the condition is true.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
if (condition) {
    // statements executed only if condition is TRUE
}

docs.title: if-else Statement
docs.text:
Used to choose between two alternative blocks.

  • if block → executes when true
  • else block → executes when false

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
if (condition) {
    // executes if TRUE
} else {
    // executes if FALSE
}

docs.title: else-if Ladder
docs.text:
Used when multiple conditions must be checked.

  • Conditions are evaluated from top to bottom
  • The first true block executes
  • Remaining conditions are skipped

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
if (condition_1) {
    // executes if condition_1 is TRUE
} else if (condition_2) {
    // executes if condition_2 is TRUE
} else if (condition_3) {
    // executes if condition_3 is TRUE
} else {
    // executes if all conditions are FALSE
}

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
int marks = 85;

if (marks >= 90) {
    System.out.println("Grade A");
} else if (marks >= 75) {
    System.out.println("Grade B");
} else if (marks >= 50) {
    System.out.println("Grade C");
} else {
    System.out.println("Fail");
}

docs.title: switch Statement
docs.text:
The switch statement compares a variable against multiple fixed constant values.

It is often cleaner and more readable than multiple else-if statements.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Works with: byte, short, int, char, String, enum
  • Uses case labels
  • break prevents fall-through
  • default runs when no case matches

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
switch (key) {

    case value_1:
        statement_1;
        break;

    case value_2:
        statement_2;
        break;

    default:
        default_statement;
}

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
int day = 2;

switch (day) {
    case 1:
        System.out.println("Monday");
        break;

    case 2:
        System.out.println("Tuesday");
        break;

    default:
        System.out.println("Invalid day");
}

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Statement Purpose if Single condition check if-else Two-way decision else-if ladder Multiple conditions switch Multiple fixed values (cleaner alternative)
